GlooKit.GlooFramework

Class KitBit

  • java.lang.Object
    • GlooKit.GlooFramework.KitBit
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Button, Canvas, Div, GlooApplication, Nook

    public abstract class KitBit
extends java.lang.Object
    KitBits are the building blocks of the Visual Gloo Framework, designed to mimic HTML elements in many ways. They are managed in a hierarchy of parents and children and are capable of multiple forms of responsive sizing. KitBits are also made to be extendable; custom KitBits can serve as modules or perform complex tasks while maintaining a uniform structure. A KitBit can have an x position, y position, width configuration, height configuration, frame, label, action, parent KitBit, and possibly many children, which are also KitBits. All of these components are described in the following paragraphs.

    Frames are the visual part of a KitBit, incorporating things like Texture. Frames implement the Drawable interface, which allows them to specify how they draw and what they do during a stepFrame or calcFrame. Labels handle the text and text formatting KitBit and may also update during a stepFrame or calcFrame. Actions are lambda functions (Runnables, specifically) that are triggered when the activate() method is called on this KitBit.

    Each KitBit will usually have a parent, which is set at construction. It may also posses multiple children, which can either be set at construction or can be adopted later via the setParent(KitBit) method.

    KitBits can be left, right, or center justified and top, bottom, or center vertical-justified within their parent elements. This allows for nine total position for a single element within its parent. In addition, they have many formatting options for their width and height in the parent element. These include options to have

    • a fixed number of pixels, which is set using the "xp" tag, where x is any number and p is the letter 'p';
    • proportional dimension to the other dimension, which is set using the "equal" tag or the "xh" or "xw" tags, where x is any number and h and w are the letters 'h' and 'w';
    • a fractional amount of the parent, which is set using the "x/y" tag, where x and y are any numbers and / is a literal slash;
    • a flexible amount of the parent, which is set using the "x/n", where x is any number, / is the literal slash, and n is the letter 'n'; or
    • size just large enough to encapsulate any of its children, which is set using the "wrap" tag.
    In addition, '+' can be appended to any of the previous, which will prevent the KitBit from having spacing between it and its neighbors. The size of fixed width or fixed height elements is determined first. Next, proportional width and proportional height elements are calculated using proportionality constants as set in the tags, where "xh" means the width is x times the height, "xw" means the height is x times the width, and "equal" means the width or height is exactly equal to the height or width. After that, fractional width and fractional height elements are calculated from the remaining space after the fixed and proportional width and height elements have been allocated. Finally, flexible amounts are determined based on a claim system. The x in the fraction x/n is the number of claims and n is the total number of claims of all children of a parent. Each flexible size child is therefore allotted (claim)/(total claims) amount of the space of the parent remaining after all fixed, proportional, and fractional width and height element have been given space. Parents who are set to "wrap" their children are calculated after all of their children have been calculated, meaning that their children must all be fixed or proportional in that direction.

    To see an example of this in action, consider 5 elements being placed in a space of 525 points where the 5 elements are formatting for width as follows (ignoring spacing):

    1. 1/4
    2. 100p
    3. 0.25h (and the height is 100p)
    4. 5/n
    5. 1/n
    As fixed width happens first, the second element is granted 100 points off the bat. Immediately afterward, the third element is awarded 25 points. This leaves 400 points, of which the first element receives 100. Finally, we have 300 points to be allocated to the two flexible width elements. Together they have 5+1=6 claims, giving the fourth element 5/6th of the 300 points and the last element the remaining 1/6th the 300 points. As such, each of the elements will be awarded:
    1. 100 points
    2. 100 points
    3. 25 points
    4. 250 points
    5. 50 points
    for this frame. If the amount of space were to change, then each of the element's widths would update accordingly. These values are calculated through the various calculate methods below and can be accessed to help set the widths of children of special KitBits, as is done by both the RowSpan and ColSpan classes.

    Up to three different methods may be called on a KitBit per frame:

    • drawFrame(float, float, float, float):
      An element is prepared for being drawn on the screen by calling the frame.draw(float, float, float, float, float) and label.draw(float, float, float, float, float) methods. In addition, most KitBits override this method to recursively call this method on their children, which ensures that all visible elements get drawn.
    • calcFrame(double, Input):
      An element processes any changes that have occurred due to user input by calling the frame.calcFrame(double, Input) and label.calcFrame(double, Input) methods only if this KitBit is not hidden. This is also recursively called on the KitBit's children. CalcFrame is only called when a KitBit or one of its ancestors is in focus and might have received user input, meaning that it will not happen every frame. As with drawFrame, this method can be overridden for more complex actions, such as button clicks.
    • stepFrame(double):
      An element processes any changes that have occurred between frames by calling the frame.stepFrame(double) and label.stepFrame(double) methods. This is also recursively called on the KitBit's children. Unlike calcFrame, this is called every frame. Like calcFrame and drawFrame, it is intended to be overridden to allow for more complex behavior, such as animation.

    The constructor for KitBits supports code formatted to resemble a markup language like HTML. For example: 

         new Room(app
       , new RowSpan(
            new ColSpan(
                 new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "0.5w", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
                ,new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "equal", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
                ,new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "equal", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
            )
            ,new ColSpan(
                 new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "1/2", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
                ,new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "1/2", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
            )
            ,new ColSpan(
                 new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "1/n", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
                ,new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "equal", "70p", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
                ,new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "1/n", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
            )
        )
     ).configure();

    KitBit is designed to be extended to allow for the writing of specialized elements that act in different ways. Almost all of the fields of KitBit are publicly accessible or have public getter methods to allow for reading. In addition, every method is public, allowing for overriding and extending as desired. Examples of simple KitBits include Canvas and Button, whereas examples of more complicated KitBits include Nook and ColSpan and RowSpan. These are also intended to be extendable, which allows for very complex behavior. In fact, extended KitBits can even serve as modules. This paired with dedicated view-controller classes creates a very responsive foundation for developing views.

    Since:
    1.0
    See Also:
    Canvas, Button, ColSpan, RowSpan, Nook, Room, GlooApplication

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void activate()
      Calls the action of this function, if there is any.
      int addChild(KitBit newChild)
      Adds a KitBit to the list of children of this KitBit, returning the index of the child in the children list.
      void calcChildren(double delta, Input input)
      Calls calcFrame(double, Input) on each of the children of this KitBit.
      void calcFrame(double delta, Input input)
      Process any changes to this element due to user input by calling the frame.calcFrame(double, Input) and label.calcFrame(double, Input) methods only if this KitBit is not hidden.
      float calculateH(KitBit child)
      Calculates the height of a child assuming that the children has no neighbors in the vertical direction.
      float calculateH(KitBit child, float spanPoints, float spanSpace)
      Calculates the height of a child given the number of points already taken by children that have fixed height and the fraction of the height of the parent available after fixed height and fractional height children have had their heights allocated. Called by a parent to figure out the heights of its children.
      float calculateHeightSpanPoints(java.util.List<KitBit> children)
      Calculates the total number of points of this KitBit that are reserved for fixed height children.
      float calculateHeightSpanSpace(java.util.List<KitBit> children)
      Calculates the fraction of the height of this KitBit that is available for flexible height children after fixed and fractional height children have had their space allocated.
      float calculateW(KitBit child)
      Calculates the width of a child assuming that the children has no neighbors in the horizontal direction.
      float calculateW(KitBit child, float spanPoints, float spanSpace)
      Calculates the width of a child given the number of points already taken by children that have fixed width and the fraction of the width of the parent available after fixed width and fractional width children have had their widths allocated.
      float calculateWidthSpanPoints(java.util.List<KitBit> children)
      Calculates the total number of points of this KitBit that are reserved for fixed width children.
      float calculateWidthSpanSpace(java.util.List<KitBit> children)
      Calculates the fraction of the width of this KitBit that is available for flexible width children after fixed and fractional width children have had their space allocated.
      float calculateX(KitBit child, float width)
      Computes the x position of a child KitBit on the screen after taking into account its justification, given the width of the child granted it by its parent.
      float calculateY(KitBit child, float height)
      Computes the y position of a child KitBit on the screen after taking into account its justification, given the height of the child granted it by its parent.
      boolean checkFocus(Input input)
      Checks to see whether this KitBit is in focus.
      void configure(float spacing, float pointSize)
      Sets the spacing and pointSize of this KitBit before recursively calling this method on all children of this KitBit.
      void destroy()
      Destroy this KitBit by ripping (removing) it from its parent's list of children after recursively calling destroy() on each of the children of this KitBit.
      void drawChildren(float Z)
      Calls drawFrame(float, float, float, float, float) on each of the children of this KitBit.
      void drawFrame(float X, float Y, float W, float H, float Z)
      Prepares this element for drawing by instructing this KitBit's frame and label to draw themselves through the frame.draw(float, float, float, float, float) and label.draw(float, float, float, float, float) methods.
      GlooApplication getApp()
      Gets the GlooApplication of this KitBit by recursively calling parent.getApp() until it reaches the GlooApplication
      java.util.List<KitBit> getChildren()
      Gets the array list of children of this element, which is a List of KitBits.
      float getSpacing()
      Gets the spacing of this element, which is the number of pixels of space between this KitBit and any of its neighbors, assuming that neither is set to fill
      void hide()
      Sets the hidden boolean of this KitBit to be true, making it invisible.
      boolean isHidden()
      Returns whether this KitBit is not visible
      boolean isHRigid()
      Returns whether this KitBit has a fixed height measured in points
      boolean isHSpaced()
      Returns whether this KitBit will reserve spacing for its height
      boolean isHWraps()
      Returns whether this KitBit's height will be the smallest possible container for the height of its child with the largest rigid height
      boolean isUnder(Vector cursor)
      Returns whether this KitBit is under the given cursor.
      boolean isWRigid()
      Returns whether this KitBit has a fixed width measured in points
      boolean isWSpaced()
      Returns whether this KitBit will reserve spacing for its width
      boolean isWWraps()
      Returns whether this KitBit's width will be the smallest possible container for the width of its child with the largest rigid width
      KitBit ripChild(int index)
      Remove and return a child from the list of children of this KitBit, given the index of the child in the list of children.
      void setAction(java.lang.Runnable action)
      Sets the action of this KitBit, which is a function that will be called when activate() is called.
      void setFrame(Drawable frame)
      Sets the frame of this KitBit, which might include the shape, Texture, and other features
      void setLabel(Label label)
      Sets the label of this KitBit, which is the text that is displayed on this element
      void setParent(KitBit parent)
      Sets the parent of this KitBit and the childIndex, which is the location of this KitBit in the parent's children list by calling the addChild(KitBit) method of the parent.
      void show()
      Sets the hidden boolean of this KitBit to be false, making it visible.
      void stepChildren(double delta)
      Calls stepFrame(double) on each of the children of this KitBit.
      void stepFrame(double delta)
      Process any changes that have happened to this element due to the passage of time between frames by calling the frame.stepFrame(double) and label.stepFrame(double) methods.

    • Constructor Detail

      • KitBit

        public KitBit(int x,
              int y,
              java.lang.String w,
              java.lang.String h)
        Creates a new KitBit given a horizontal and vertical justification and width and height formatting. Overloads the other constructor to not have any children. See the other constructor for a full description of the parameters.
        Parameters:
        x - int of the horizontal justification, which can take values of LEFT, RIGHT, or CENTER (defaults to CENTER)
        y - int of the vertical justification, which can take values of TOP, BOTTOM, or CENTER (defaults to CENTER)
        w - a valid formatting String for setting the width.
        h - a valid formatting String for setting the height.
        See Also:
        KitBit(int, int, String, String, KitBit...)

      • KitBit

        public KitBit(int x,
              int y,
              java.lang.String w,
              java.lang.String h,
              KitBit... children)
        Creates a new KitBit given a horizontal and vertical justification, width and height formatting, and possibly multiple children. There are nine possible combinations of values for the horizontal and vertical justification in addition to many formatting options for w (width) and h (height), as specified below. Note that w and h cannot both be equal or xh and xw.

        The formatting of taking multiple children allows for KitBits within a menu or screen to be written in a vaguely HTML-like way. For example: 

             new Room(app
       , new RowSpan(
            new ColSpan(
                 new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "0.5w", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
                ,new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "equal", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
                ,new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "equal", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
            )
            ,new ColSpan(
                 new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "1/2", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
                ,new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "1/2", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
            )
            ,new ColSpan(
                 new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "1/n", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
                ,new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "equal", "70p", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
                ,new Canvas(LEFT, CENTER, "1/n", "1/n", new Rect(blue, DEFAULT))
            )
        )
     ).configure();
        Parameters:
        x - int of the horizontal justification, which can take values of LEFT, RIGHT, or CENTER (defaults to CENTER)
        y - int of the vertical justification, which can take values of TOP, BOTTOM, or CENTER (defaults to CENTER)
        w - a valid formatting String for setting the width. Can take several values:
        • xp
        • x/y
        • x/n
        • equal
        • xh
        • wrap
        • + appended to any of the previous
        where x and y are integers and every other character is the literal character (except the words in the last item). Each of these has a different meaning:
        • A specific number of points (200p means 200 points wide). One point is roughly equivalent to 1/72 inches.
        • Some fraction of the available width (2/5 means 40% the available width) after points have been allocated.
        • Primarily useful in RowSpans, where multiple elements are in a row. After points have been allocated and specified fractions have been allocated (see above), there will be some amount of space left. Each remaining element that specified some x/n will receive x shares out of the remaining space. For example, two elements with 1/n and 2/n with a remaining space of 600 points will receive 200 and 400 points, respectively.
        • Width is exactly equal to the height
        • Width is proportional to height (0.5h means width is half the height)
        • Width is the smallest possible container for the largest width amongst its children
        • Appending + to any of these means that the KitBit will not have spacing around it in the x direction. By default the KitBit will have spacing.
        For a full example of this, consider 4 elements being placed in a space of 400 points where one element requests 100p, one element requests 1/3, one element requests 2/n, and the last element requests 3/n. For simplicity, spacing is neglected in this example. In this case, the first element is immediately granted 100 points, leaving 300 points. The second element is granted 1/3rd of the remaining 300 points, giving it another 100 points. The last two elements requested a total of 5 shares of the remaining 200 points, giving the first of the two 2/5ths of 200 points and the second 3/5ths of 200, giving them 80 and 120 points, respectively.
        h - a valid formatting String for setting the height. Can take several values:
        • xp
        • x/y
        • x/n
        • equal
        • xw
        • wrap
        • + appended to any of the previous
        where x and y are integers and every other character is the literal character (except the words in the last item). Each of these has a different meaning:
        • A specific number of points (200p means 200 points tall). One point is roughly equivalent to 1/72 inches.
        • Some fraction of the available height (2/5 means 40% the available height) after points have been allocated.
        • Primarily useful in ColSpans, where multiple elements are in a column. After points have been allocated and specified fractions have been allocated (see above), there will be some amount of space left. Each remaining element that specified some x/n will receive x shares out of the remaining space. For example, two elements with 1/n and 2/n with a remaining space of 600 points will receive 200 and 400 points, respectively.
        • Height is exactly equal to the width
        • Height is proportional to width (0.25w means height is one quarter the width)
        • Height is the smallest possible container for the largest height amongst its children
        • Appending + to any of these means that the KitBit will not have spacing around it in the y direction. By default the KitBit will have spacing.
        For a full example of this, consider 4 elements being placed in a space of 400 points where one element requests 100p, one element requests 1/3, one element requests 2/n, and the last element requests 3/n. For simplicity, spacing is neglected in this example. In this case, the first element is immediately granted 100 points, leaving 300 points. The second element is granted 1/3rd of the remaining 300 points, giving it another 100 points. The last two elements requested a total of 5 shares of the remaining 200 points, giving the first of the two 2/5ths of 200 points and the second 3/5ths of 200, giving them 80 and 120 points, respectively.
        children - possibly many KitBits, which are children of this KitBit. Can take any number of KitBits.

    • Method Detail

      • addChild

        public int addChild(KitBit newChild)
        Adds a KitBit to the list of children of this KitBit, returning the index of the child in the children list. If the child has previously been added, returns the index where the child already was. Added children go in the first empty slot of the list, only appending to the list if necessary.
        Parameters:
        newChild - a KitBit to add to the list of children of this KitBit
        Returns:
        int for the index of the child in the list of children

      • activate

        public void activate()
        Calls the action of this function, if there is any. This method should be overridden if the action is not a Runnable, but instead something like a Consumer or BiConsumer.

      • calcChildren

        public void calcChildren(double delta,
                         Input input)
        Calls calcFrame(double, Input) on each of the children of this KitBit. This method is here primarily to allow for possible overrides, if desired.
        Parameters:
        delta - double for the number of seconds between the previous frame and the current frame
        input - an Input, which handles user input from keyboards, mice and controllers and is typically passed down by the parent of this KitBit
        See Also:
        calcFrame(double, Input)

      • calcFrame

        public void calcFrame(double delta,
                      Input input)
        Process any changes to this element due to user input by calling the frame.calcFrame(double, Input) and label.calcFrame(double, Input) methods only if this KitBit is not hidden. Also calls calcChildren(double, Input), which recursively calls calcFrame on each of the children of this KitBit.

        CalcFrame is only called when a KitBit or one of its ancestors is in focus and might have received user input. This default method does not actually do anything but pass the call on to the frame and label and the children of this KitBit, but it can be overloaded to do something fancier. For an example of this, see Button.calcFrame(double, Input).

        Parameters:
        delta - double for the number of seconds between the previous frame and the current frame
        input - an Input, which handles user input from keyboards, mice and controllers and is typically passed down by the parent of this KitBit
        See Also:
        stepFrame(double)

      • calculateH

        public float calculateH(KitBit child)
        Calculates the height of a child assuming that the children has no neighbors in the vertical direction. This method is called by a parent to figure out the height of its children.
        Parameters:
        child - the KitBit child of this KitBit whose height is being calculated
        Returns:
        float for the height of this child, measured in pixels
        See Also:
        calculateH(KitBit, float, float)

      • calculateH

        public float calculateH(KitBit child,
                        float spanPoints,
                        float spanSpace)
        Calculates the height of a child given
        • the number of points already taken by children that have fixed height and
        • the fraction of the height of the parent available after fixed height and fractional height children have had their heights allocated.
        Called by a parent to figure out the heights of its children.
        Parameters:
        child - the KitBit child of this KitBit whose height is being calculated
        spanPoints - the number of points already taken by children of this KitBit who have fixed height, calculated by calculateHeightSpanPoints(List)
        spanSpace - the fraction of the height of this KitBit available after children with fixed or fractional heights have been allocated, calculated by calculateHeightSpanSpace(List)
        Returns:
        float for the height of this child, measured in pixels

      • calculateHeightSpanPoints

        public float calculateHeightSpanPoints(java.util.List<KitBit> children)
        Calculates the total number of points of this KitBit that are reserved for fixed height children.
        Parameters:
        children - the list of children of this parent whose heights are being calculated
        Returns:
        the total number of points taken by fixed height children as a float

      • calculateHeightSpanSpace

        public float calculateHeightSpanSpace(java.util.List<KitBit> children)

        Parameters:
        children - the list of children of this parent whose heights are being calculated
        Returns:
        the fraction of the height available for flexible height children as a float

      • checkFocus

        public boolean checkFocus(Input input)
        Checks to see whether this KitBit is in focus. By default, this simply checks to see if the element is under the cursor through the isUnder(Vector) method, but this can be overridden for more complex behavior.
        Parameters:
        input - an Input, which handles user input from keyboards, mice and controllers and is typically passed down by the parent of this KitBit
        Returns:
        true if this KitBit is in focus

      • configure

        public void configure(float spacing,
                      float pointSize)
        Sets the spacing and pointSize of this KitBit before recursively calling this method on all children of this KitBit. This method can be overridden to change the pointsSize or spacing of a child relative to its parent's.
        Parameters:
        spacing - float for the number of pixels in the spacing between this element and its neighbors
        pointSize - float for the number of pixels per point for this element

      • destroy

        public void destroy()
        Destroy this KitBit by ripping (removing) it from its parent's list of children after recursively calling destroy() on each of the children of this KitBit. Deletes the list of children referencing this KitBit and reference of this KitBit's parent to this, thereby removing all references to this KitBit. It will eventually be garbage collected.

      • drawChildren

        public void drawChildren(float Z)
        Calls drawFrame(float, float, float, float, float) on each of the children of this KitBit. Calculates the position and size of each child under the assumption that each child has no neighbors (or doesn't care about its neighbors). This method is here primarily to allow for possible overrides, if desired.
        Parameters:
        Z - float for the z-coordinate of the this KitBit
        See Also:
        drawFrame(float, float, float, float, float)

      • drawFrame

        public void drawFrame(float X,
                      float Y,
                      float W,
                      float H,
                      float Z)
        Prepares this element for drawing by instructing this KitBit's frame and label to draw themselves through the frame.draw(float, float, float, float, float) and label.draw(float, float, float, float, float) methods. Although this method does not inherently call on all of the children of this KitBit to draw themselves, it can be overridden to do so by also calling the drawChildren(float), which is done by many specialized KitBits. This method is almost always called by the parent KitBit, meaning that the parent is responsible for determining and passing all variables to the children. This also stores the values of X, Y, W and H that are passed for use later when checking focus or determining width and height.
        Parameters:
        X - float for the horizontal position of the bottom left corner of this KitBit on the screen, measured in pixels from the left side of the screen
        Y - float for the vertical position of the bottom left corner of this KitBit on the screen, measured in pixels from the bottom of the screen
        W - float for the width of this KitBit on the screen, measured in pixels
        H - float for the height of this KitBit on the screen, measured in pixels
        Z - float for the z-coordinate of this KitBit on the screen, ranging from -1 to +1, where +1 is closest to the screen and -1 is furthest from the screen. This does not change the width or height of this KitBit but determines whether this KitBit is drawn in front of or behind another KitBit.

        public GlooApplication getApp()
        Gets the GlooApplication of this KitBit by recursively calling parent.getApp() until it reaches the GlooApplication
        Returns:
        the GlooApplication that this KitBit is an element in

        action - a Runnable, which is the function that will be called when activate() is triggered on this KitBit

        Sets the label of this KitBit, which is the text that is displayed on this element

      • setParent

        public void setParent(KitBit parent)
        Sets the parent of this KitBit and the childIndex, which is the location of this KitBit in the parent's children list by calling the addChild(KitBit) method of the parent.
        Parameters:
        parent - the KitBit that this KitBit will be a child of

      • show

        public void show()
        Sets the hidden boolean of this KitBit to be false, making it visible.

      • stepChildren

        public void stepChildren(double delta)
        Calls stepFrame(double) on each of the children of this KitBit. This method is here primarily to allow for possible overrides, if desired.
        Parameters:
        delta - double of the number of seconds between the previous frame and the current frame
        See Also:
        stepFrame(double)

      • stepFrame

        public void stepFrame(double delta)
        Process any changes that have happened to this element due to the passage of time between frames by calling the frame.stepFrame(double) and label.stepFrame(double) methods. Also calls stepChildren(double), which recursively calls stepFrame on each of the children of this KitBit.

        Unlike calcFrame, stepFrame is called on every object for every frame, regardless of whether they are hidden or in focus through the recursive nature of the stepChildren method. This default method does not actually do anything but pass the call on to the frame and label and the children of this KitBit, but it can be overloaded to do something fancier.

        Parameters:
        delta - double of the number of seconds between the previous frame and the current frame
        See Also:
        calcFrame(double, Input)
